extraction_metadata.article_title: The Impact of Open Source Software Commercialization on Firm Value

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Open Source Software (OSS) Commercialization - A business model where firms commercialize open source software products through complementary proprietary products/services while leveraging IPR protection mechanisms
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'Vendors of proprietary software products are increasingly moving to business models inspired by open source software (OSS). This study investigates sources of heterogeneity in value appropriation associated with commercializing OSS.' | Page 6: 'Firms that adopt the open innovation model integrate these external sources...OSS, which is freely available to all parties that accept the licensing terms of the software, is the outcome of such an open innovation model'

extracted_data.question_text: What synonyms or alternative terms are used in the article to refer to this software business model?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'relying solely on an open business model remains too risky in competitive markets' | Page 4: 'private-collective model of innovation' | Page 432: 'Hybrid Business Models in the Open Source Software Industry'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the main vertical segment or industry where the software business model presented in the article is applied?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'companies operating in software-related industries from the Fortune Global 500 list' | Page 8: 'reports of product introductions that included the phrases "open source" or "Linux" indicated possible OSS product introductions'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the target customer type of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'companies operating in software-related industries from the Fortune Global 500 list' | Page 6: 'firms that aim to develop a commercial product jointly with a community do so mainly to receive design help from their potential future customers'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the typical size of offering companies that adopt this software business model as described in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Large technology corporations from Fortune Global 500
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'companies operating in software-related industries from the Fortune Global 500 list' | Page 9: '28 introduced at least one OSS product to the market during the 7-year period'

extracted_data.extracted_value: Large software corporations seeking to commercialize OSS products
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'for-profit firms collaborating with OSS communities' | Page 6: 'firms that aim to develop a commercial product jointly with a community do so mainly to receive design help from their potential future customers'

extracted_value: Software trademarks → Brand protection but negative impact on OSS commercialization

extracted_data.source_citation: Page 10: 'create a marketplace for complementary proprietary products and services' - refers to conceptual marketplace, not cloud marketplaces

extracted_data.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Open source software with commercial extensions and support
Customer Segment: Large enterprises and software corporations
Revenue Streams: Complementary proprietary products and services
Key Resources: Software patents and trademarks
Key Activities: OSS commercialization and IPR management
Cost Structure: IPR protection and patent portfolio development
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 10: 'commercial OSS releases ensure diffusion and create a marketplace for complementary proprietary products and services' | Page 3: 'appropriating returns from commercializing OSS products depends critically on firms' stocks of software patents and trademarks'

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Firms | Commercial OSS providers | Develop and release OSS products | Collaborate with communities | Communities | Volunteer developers | Contribute code and feedback | Interact with firms | Customers | End users | Purchase complementary products | Receive support from firms | Patent holders | Technology suppliers | Provide patent protection | May threaten litigation
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 6: 'companies collaborate with communities of volunteer developers' | Page 4: 'firms that cannot secure access to the underlying technology because of strong patenting activity and the high threat of litigation' | Page 6: 'customers, suppliers, competitors and universities'

extracted_data.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 6: 'identifying, exploiting and integrating external knowledge into internal research-and-development activities' | Page 4: 'potential complementarity between the patented software and commercial OSS products' | Page 2: 'OSS releases is usually a strategic move (e.g., to weaken a competitor)'

extracted_data.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Large software patent stocks → Higher firm value
Strategic IPR portfolio alignment → Better returns
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 9: 'software patent stocks positively affect the relationship between a firm's OSS product portfolio and its value' | Page 10: 'commercial OSS releases ensure diffusion and create a marketplace for complementary proprietary products and services'

extracted_data.question_text: What prerequisites or conditions are necessary for the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'appropriating returns from commercializing OSS products depends critically on firms' stocks of software patents and trademarks' | Page 6: 'firms that adopt the open innovation model integrate these external sources'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Software trademarks → Negative impact on OSS commercialization
Patent thickets → Transaction costs and commercialization barriers
Brand investments → Conflict with open source values
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 9: 'software trademark stocks have a negative effect on this relationship' | Page 4: 'patent thickets create transaction costs and reduce the demand for the new technology' | Page 4: 'tight control of IPR discourages participation in OSS projects'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'relying solely on an open business model remains too risky in competitive markets' | Page 4: 'the main challenge of reaping the benefits from it' | Page 4: 'credible holdup threats'

extracted_data.question_text: What practices are used to mitigate challenges of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Software patent portfolio → Litigation protection → Competitive advantage
Strategic IPR alignment → Value appropriation → Higher firm value
Community engagement → Innovation input → Product development
Complementary asset investment → Revenue streams → Business sustainability
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'large stocks operate as strategic tools to sell complementary products/services' | Page 4: 'they allow the firm to avoid holdups and litigation threats by technology suppliers' | Page 6: 'firms that adopt the open innovation model integrate these external sources'

extracted_data.question_text: What metrics and quantitative results are reported in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Tobin's Q; Various values; Ratio; 2003-2009; Statistical analysis; Financial databases | OSS Portfolio; Cumulative count; Products; 1999-2009; 15% discount rate; PROMT database | Software Patents; Cumulative count; Patents; 1999-2009; 15% discount rate; USPTO database | Software Trademarks; Cumulative count; Trademarks; 1999-2009; 15% discount rate; USPTO database
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 8: 'Tobin's q serves as the dependent variable, which offers a forward-looking proxy for firm value' | Page 8: 'I computed the cumulative number of OSS product announcements to proxy for a firm's OSS product portfolio' | Page 9: '490 firm-year (70 firms × 7 years) observations'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the temporal period and maturity of the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'panel data of 70 companies covering a seven year period from 2003 to 2009' | Page 2: 'Vendors of proprietary software products are increasingly moving to business models inspired by open source software (OSS)'

extracted_data.question_text: Which companies or products are cited as examples of the software business model in the article?

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Low OSS Portfolio → Limited commercialization approach
High OSS Portfolio → Extensive commercialization strategy
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 9: 'I split the data for firms that commercialize OSS into two, as LowOssPortfolio and HighOssPortfolio' | Page 4: 'private-collective model of innovation' | Page 432: 'Hybrid Business Models in the Open Source Software Industry'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Increasing adoption by proprietary software vendors
Growing importance of IPR protection mechanisms
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'Vendors of proprietary software products are increasingly moving to business models inspired by open source software (OSS)' | Page 7: 'commercialization of OSS is a rising trend' | Page 395: 'The transformation of OSS into a commercial strategy has obliged firms to reconsider their current business models'
